Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Pituitrin in Cardiac Surgery Patients with Pulmonary Hypertension

Participants.evidence: 300 adult patients with pulmonary hypertension scheduled for elective cardiac surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomized to receive either continuous intravenous infusion of pituitrin at 0.04 U/(kg h) or normal saline

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of pituitrin, a vasopressin and oxytocin substitute, in improving postoperative outcomes in these patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was a composite endpoint of all-cause mortality or common complications within 30 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated, with allocation concealed in opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors and patients were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: The study enrolled 300 participants, with 150 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome's effect size and precision will be reported upon study completion.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events, including mild gastrointestinal side effects, were monitored, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing such events.

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by The First Hospital affiliated with Shandong First Medical University.
